object.course_desc: Seminar in selected topics related to Urbanism at an introductory level.
object.course_extra_details: Lecture and discussion three hours per week.

object.course_desc: Primary structural, spatial and formal organization and elements that characterize the morphology of cities; historical and contemporary significance for architecture and urban design. (Core).
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): First-year standing in the B.A.S. Urbanism major, second or third-year standing in other B.A.S. majors, or permission of the School.
Lecture two hours a week and tutorial one hour a week.
object.course_prerequisites: First-year standing in the B.A.S. Urbanism major, second or third-year standing in other B.A.S. majors, or permission of the School.

object.course_desc: Practical significance of landscape elements as they relate to built-form by integrating structure and site. (Workshop).
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): permission of the School.
Lecture, seminar, lab or field work six hours a week.

object.course_desc: Project-based workshop investigating current design attitudes and solutions affecting the physical morphology of cities. Formally sophisticated urban design projects. Various procedures and basic urban design ideas. (Workshop).
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): permission of the School.
Lecture, seminar, lab or field work six hours a week.

object.course_desc: Interdisciplinary investigation, analysis and synthesis of the institutions, processes, environments and demography of Canadian cities. Guest lecturers. (Workshop).
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): permission of the School.
Lecture, seminar, lab or field work six hours a week.

object.course_desc: A specific aspect of architecture in the area of urban studies. Topics vary from year to year. (Workshop).
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for ARCU4103.
Prerequisite(s): permission of the School.
Lecture, seminar, lab or field work six hours a week.

object.course_desc: Course addresses cities such as Istanbul, Mexico City, Venice, Paris, Ottawa, Mumbai, and New Orleans. Topics presented by the instructor and guests include environmental resilience and climate change; social justice and informal settlement; smart cities and data privacy; and urban design, memory, and imagination.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for ARCU3902.
Prerequisite(s): Second-year standing or permission of the Instructor.
Lecture two hours per week and tutorial one hour per week.
object.course_prerequisites: Second-year standing or permission of the Instructor.

object.course_desc: Contemporary urban theory and critical scholarship that engages evolving social, political, economic and environmental perspectives, addresses multiple scales, geographic contexts, and disciplinary boundaries, and investigates the expanding array of models, tools and techniques that have contributed to various theories of urbanism.

Structure, form and functioning of cities. Infra-structure, facilities and networks, ecosystems, demographic and social organization, government, quality of life, goals and perceptions, urban management, development, regulation and codes, design, planning and policy-making. (Elective Course).
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for ARCU 3400.
Three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Background factors pertaining to housing in both industrial and developing countries; traditional and contemporary housing approaches; social housing; and people's right to adequate housing. Guest lecturers. (Elective Course).
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for ARCU 3500.
Three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Urban renewal in the post-war period in response to housing shortages, suburbanization, transportation infrastructure and other factors. Gentrification and the emerging form of the post-industrial city, including new urbanism and sustainable communities. Case studies from Canada, Europe and the U.S. (Theory/History Elective).
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): ARCU3100 and third or fourth-year standing in the B.A.S. Urbanism program or permission of the School.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: ARCU3100 and third or fourth-year standing in the B.A.S. Urbanism program or permission of the School.

object.course_desc: Urban utopias throughout history, with emphasis on the 20th century. Garden Cities, anti-urbanism and radical decentralization, the city in the region, Italian Rationalist cities, Le Corbusier and CIAM, post-WWII New Towns (England, Scandinavia and the US), Sustainable Urbanism.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): third or fourth-year standing in B.A.S. Urbanism program or permission of the School.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third or fourth-year standing in B.A.S. Urbanism program or permission of the School.

object.course_desc: Advanced seminar in selected topics related to urbanism.   Topics may include histories and theories related to urban systems, design, and planning. (Core course).
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing in B.A.S. (Urbanism) or permission of the Instructor.
Seminar three hours per week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing in B.A.S. (Urbanism) or permission of the Instructor.

object.course_desc: Advanced investigation into issues related to urbanism and urban form. Topics will vary from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing in B.A.S. (Urbanism) or permission of Instructor.
Lecture three hours per week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing in B.A.S. (Urbanism) or permission of Instructor.
